lines.Vitus: "Why don't we ask Makari-Hari to join us?"

lines.Volesus: "I don't think divine beings need to bathe."

lines.Vitus: "It's true. He does always smell immaculate."

lines.Volesus: "Besides, if he wanted to join, he would already behere."

lines.Vitus: "Well, I can never tell when they're here or not."

lines.Makari-Hari: "It is wise to be cautious of the divine, mortal."

lines.Volesus: "You can say caution is just another form of respect."

lines.Vitus: "I suppose that's one way of looking at it."

lines.Makari-Hari: "For what reason have you called upon me?"
"Do not keep me waiting, Crown Mages..."

lines.Vitus: "Well, to be frank, it's embarrassing to admit how little I know about you."
"I wasn't exactly raised to be a devout follower of the Clergy."

lines.Makari-Hari: "That's probably for the best."
"Your ideas would be wrong and twisted. At least they would be based on what I have seen of my followers in this era."

lines.Vitus: "Then why don't we talk about something a little more personal?"

lines.Volesus: "We were curious about whether or not you'd join us in the bath."

lines.Makari-Hari: "...Why would you ask such a foolish question?"
"Baths are delightful!"
"One moment."

lines: (We expect the god to approach the changing room, but instead he begins to remove his clothes in front of us.)

lines.Vitus: "Wait, he's just going to strip right here?!"

lines.Makari-Hari: "There is nothing impure about nudity. It is just another aspect of creation."

lines.Vitus: "W-Wait, then why did you change into some sort of magic bath towel?!"

lines.Makari-Hari: "A god does not need to relax."
"Relaxation is but a convention to distract you from the truth that your mental faculties degrade with time."
"Divinity is eternal."
"But if you remain curious, I fashioned this towel as I will not enter the water in my ceremonial attire."
"Now that would be deranged."

lines.Vitus: "He could rent a real towel if he wanted."

lines.Volesus: "Hard to fill out the form when you're invisible."

lines.Makari-Hari: "You two, sit beside me."
"Now tell me... why do they put oranges in the water here?"

lines.Volesus: "The oils from the citrus fruit diffuse from a high concentration in the oranges to a low concentration in the liquid solvent."

lines.Makari-Hari: "I know the inner workings of this world. No need to patronise me."
"Tell me what mortals feel when they engage in such disorderly things."
"So what you mean is that mortals stave off their own entropy with the scents of life."
"Even though the oranges appear to be disorderly, there is order within it."
"Delightful."
"That is all I wished to ask."
